attributes.title: Self-esteem Importance Scale X Ambivalence X Certainty (Study 2)
attributes.description: Extending Study 1's results concerning certainty ratings of importance, into an analysis of ambivalence and certainty.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Self-esteem Importance Ambivalence: Interest in Self-esteem Feedback Conceptual Replication

other.value: Yes: we would like the sample size to be at least approximately equal in the two experimental conditions. Therefore, if the sample size in the cash draw group is 75% or smaller the sample size of the self-esteem feedback group after the first week, we will tweak the reminder email to increase the size of the cash reward. We will do this without calculating SEI+/- in any way, so we cannot check on our main hypothesis when doing this.

sample.value: About 1900 individuals will be invited to participate. However, we cannot precisely estimate what our sample size will be because it will depend on the show-up rate. In a previous study we emailed ~1900 people and 493 people responded, so a reasonable guess would be that we would again obtain about n = 500. However, this is only a guess and the previous study was run earlier in that year’s academic year. Because we are running the present study in February, there is a good chance that less people will be interested in doing any studies, decreasing our effective sample size.

analyses.value:
We will conduct two simple t-tests, which examine whether advertising condition (cash award vs. self-esteem feedback) is associated with a difference in the average SEIS-Positive and/or SEIS-Negative scores of people who complete the study.
We hypothesize that SEIS-Positive and –Negative scores will each be higher in the self-esteem feedback condition relative to the cash award condition.
We will also attempt to control for possible differences in simple trait self-esteem when looking at this difference in a regression framework. That is,
Condition (contrast-coded) + trait self-esteem --> self-esteem importance (positive)
And
Condition (contrast-coded) + trait self-esteem --> self-esteem importance (negative)

outliers.value: We will only retain scores from participants who complete the ENTIRE survey in each given condition, since our interest is in the completion of a study for a given reward, not initial attraction.

dependent.value: The main DV is continuous scores on our two scales: the scale of self-esteem importance (positive) and the scale of self-esteem importance (negative).

conditions.value:
All possible participants will be assigned to one of two conditions, in which they are invited to participate in a study in exchange only for personality (self-esteem) feedback, OR for a cash award. They will be given two weeks to complete the survey after the invitation is sent out, to help avoid the risk that some participants may not complete the survey due to irrelevant reasons (e.g. if we ran the survey for only a couple of days, participants might simply have a few exams on those days, creating an artificial barrier against their participating). We reason that two weeks should provide an adequate time to complete the brief survey, including two weekends during which participants should hopefully be freed to respond.
Using a Qualtrics function, individuals who have not completed the survey after the first week will receive an automatic reminder from Qualtrics reminding them that they only have seven days left, and reminding them that they can get self-esteem feedback (vs cash award) by completing it.

hypothesis.value:
We will be contacting participants from a large prescreen list via email. These individuals will be invited to learn about their self-esteem by completing a very quick study, or to receive an entry into a cash draw. In reality, regardless of condition, they will indeed receive bona fide feedback about their relative self-esteem levels, reported as low/medium/high based on normative data we collected through an earlier prescreening process – and also be entered into a cash draw. Therefore, the only difference among participants is whether their invitation email focuses on getting accurate self-esteem feedback, or focuses on getting a possible cash award.
Each participant is directed to a Qualtrics survey in which they fill out a consent form, then complete the BFI-44 (a 44 item scale that takes under five minutes to complete), the Self-Esteem Importance Scale (a 20-item scale that takes about two minutes to complete), and the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (a 10-item scale that takes about one minute to complete). The inclusion of the BFI is to provide some “work” for participants to do; after all, people who are highly motivated to learn about self-esteem should be willing to answer some self-esteem irrelevant items to get to the self-esteem feedback that they desire. The SEIS has been included so we can assess a roughly four-month test-retest reliability of that measure. Afterwards, participants receive genuine information feedback about their trait self-esteem based on their actual scores. That is, participants with low self-esteem (below 25th percentile) get one kind of feedback, whereas participants with high self-esteem (above 75th) get a different feedback. Those in the middle get told that their self-esteem is moderate. (See materials for specific feedback provided.)
At the end of the study, we will explain the true purpose of the study to participants in a debriefing form: all that we are interested in is who did this ‘bonus study’ whose sole reward is learning about their self-esteem (vs cash award). We hypothesize that self-esteem importance scores should be elevated in the study version that is only reinforced with accurate self-esteem feedback, compared to the study version in which cash incentives are used. The logic is that people who think that self-esteem leads to important consequences – positive or negative – should be more motivated to learn about their self-esteem levels, since knowing this information should be more consequential in their minds. However, they should not be any more interested in receiving a cash award (a very general and non-specific reinforcer).

attributes.title: Supporting adolescents to thrive despite uncertainty

q1.value: Supporting adolescents to thrive despite uncertainty: An analysis of the psychological correlates of paradoxical knowing

q2.value: The Motivation Lab, Irmak Olcaysoy Okten

q3.value:
The present study aims to investigate what makes students vulnerable to holding a "paradoxical knowledge," namely, having strong feelings of certainty for the things that are technically unknowable. It will also analyze potential academic and interpersonal correlates that may make this shortcut to knowledge problematic for the person who has fallen prey to it (e.g., showing impulsive thinking) as well as for the people around them (e.g., whether paradoxical knowing is related to a determination to ignore opposing views of others). 

Our research questions are as follows:
1) Can the phenomenon of paradoxical knowing (one's claim to know something while recognizing its unknowability) be measured among high school students (qualitatively and quantitatively)?
2) Does adolescents’ chronic tendency to hold paradoxical knowledge relate to antisocial behaviors and intuitive thinking (as observed in adults previously)?
3. Are there other correlates of paradoxical knowledge (other than the factors observed in previous studies), including one’s avoidance of taking responsibility for their own actions (e.g., externalization), social isolation, and lack of intellectual humility?

q4.value:
We hypothesize that paradoxical knowing will be significantly related to the following variables:

-Greater anti-social behaviors (determined ignorance and aggression)
-Greater intuitive thinking (higher self-reported impulsivity, higher behavioral impulsivity, lower need for cognition)
-Greater social isolation (a lower level of social belonging and the feeling of being understood, a greater level of perception of self-victimhood)
-A lower level of taking responsibility for one's own actions (higher externalization, detachment, and stonewalling)
-A lower level of intellectual humility

We hypothesize that paradoxical knowing will not be related to the following variables: 

-Self-esteem
-Depression
-Self-efficacy

We will explore the relationship between paradoxical knowing and the following variables: 

-Bullying experiences (getting bullied and bullying)
-School performance (Self-reported (objective) school performance, subjective school performance, GPA)
-Self-perception on the traits of tenderness, gentle-heartedness, forcefulness, assertiveness, kindness, dominance
-Defensiveness, contempt, and criticism
-Shame and guilt
-Empathy and perspective-taking
-Adolescent attachment style
-Trait anxiety
-Regret
-Narcissism

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Correlational Design

q9.value: Participants will be randomized into conditions at the individual-level through logic built into our Qualtrics survey.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network (CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.
 
CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.
 
CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers.
 
For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer to https://characterlab.org/research-network.

q13.value: We anticipate that approximately 1000-1200 students will participate in this study. However, this number may vary depending on the success of recruitment at the schools.

q14.value: A power analysis suggests that for an alpha level of .05, an effect size of 0.12 and 80% power, 1090 would be required for this study.

question.value: There are no manipulated variables in this study.

Paradoxical knowing (PK) (open-ended): Participants are asked to report one personal experience of paradoxical knowing in an open-ended fashion. 
Ease of PK recall: One question of rating the ease of recalling the PK experience that was just reported (1: Extremely easy, 7: Extremely difficult). 
Determined ignorance: Five items assessing the tendency to ignore others’ opinions (e.g., “You don't really have to consider all information.” (Gollwitzer & Oettingen, 2019). 
PK (chronic), Concordant Knowing, Believing, Concordant not knowing, Paradoxical not Knowing: Each of the five variables is measured through three items, rated on a 7 point scale (1: Not at all agree, 7: Strongly agree) (Gollwitzer & Oettingen, 2019). 
Empathy and Perspective Taking: Seven item subscales of each borrowed from the Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davis, 1980) (e.g., “I am often quite touched by things that I see happen.”, “When I'm upset at someone, I usually try to "put myself in his shoes" for a while.”). 
Self-reported (objective) school performance: One item measuring average score in the current school year (options: less than 60%, 60-69%. 70-79%, 80% or high, don’t know). Getting bullied: The frequency of getting bullied since the start of the school year rated on a 5-item scale, (0: Not at all-4: Many times a week) (Wang et al., 2014). 
Bullying: The frequency of bullying others since the start of the school year rated on a 5-item scale, (0: Not at all-4: Many times a week) (Wang et al., 2014). 
Aggression: The tendency to hold aggressive attitudes, measured through 5 items on a 7-point scale (1: Strongly disagree, 7: Strongly agree) (e.g., “In general, the only way to rid the world of bad ideas is through the use of force.”, Crowson, 2009). 
Self-reported impulsiveness: The tendency of impulsivity and restraint measured via four items (2 items for each subscale) selected from the Brief Self-control Scale (1: Not at all like me, 5: Very much like me) (Tangney et al., 2004) (e.g., “I have a hard time breaking bad habits.”). 
Behavioral impulsiveness: Measured via Cognitive Reflection Task (Frederick, 2005), including three calculation questions. 
Perceived victimhood: Perception of being a victim compared to others, measured via three items on a 7-point scale (1: Strongly disagree, 7: Strongly agree) (e.g., “In general, I have suffered more than most of my peers.”, adapted from Noor et al., 2008). 
Need for cognition: Measured via three items selected from Keller et al. (2019) on a 7 point scale (1: Not true at all, 7: Extremely true) (e.g., “I like to do puzzles.”). 
Feeling of being understood: Measured via five items adapted from Livingstone et al. (2019), rated on a 7-point scale (1: Not true at all, 7: Extremely true) (e.g., “My peers generally understand my values.”). 
Intellectual humility: Measured via five items selected from Leary et al. (2017), rated on a 7-point scale (1: Not at all like me, 7: Very much like me) (e.g., “I accept that my beliefs and attitudes may be wrong”). 
Self-efficacy:  Measuring academic, social, and emotional self-efficacy (1 item per each) selected from Muris’ (2001) scale, rated on a 7-point scale (1: Not well at all, 7: Extremely well). 
Subjective school performance: Rating of self-performance regardless of grades, how well they think they perform at school (1: Extremely poorly, 7: Extremely Well), and their certainty for subjective academic performance (1: Not certain at all, 7: Extremely certain).
Four horsemen of the apocalypse: Criticism, contempt, stonewalling and defensiveness measured via three items (each) selected from Fowler & Dillow’s (2011) scale, rated on a 7-point scale (1: Not true at all, 7: Extremely True) (e.g., for stonewalling, “If I can tell a disagreement is brewing, I kind of shut down and stop talking.”). 
Regret: Measured via five items selected from Schwartz et al. (2002) and on a 7-point scale (1: Strongly disagree, 7: Strongly agree) (e.g., “Whenever I make a choice, I’m curious about what would have happened if I had chosen differently.”). 
Self-Attributional Style (shame, guilt, detachment, and externalization): Measured through TOSCA (Tangney et al., 1991), where participants rate their likelihood of engaging in those four different types of responses in four different (selected) scenarios, rated on a 5-point scale (1: Not at all likely, 5: Very likely) (e.g., “While playing around, you throw a ball, and it hits your friend in the face.”). 
Self-esteem: One item of self-reported self-esteem on a 7-point scale (“I have high self-esteem”; 1: Not at all true of me, 7: Extremely true of me). 
Social belonging: 2 items borrowed from Ingram (2012), rated on a 7-point scale, 1: Strongly disagree, 7: Strongly Agree). 
Self-Trait judgments: Participants evaluate themselves on six traits (tender, gentle-hearted, forceful, assertive, kind, dominant) on a 7-point scale (1: Extremely inaccurate, 7: Extremely accurate). 
Narcissism: Measured via three items from the Childhood Narcissism Scale (Thomaes et al., 2008) on a 4-point scale (0: Not at all true, 3: Completely True) (e.g., “Kids like me deserve something extra”). 
Trait Anxiety: Frequency of symptoms measured via four items selected from Spielberger (1983), rated on a 4-point scale (0: Not at all, 3: Very much so). 
Depression: Measured via a short version of CES-D with 12 items (experience of certain psychological states in the last seven days) rated on a 4-point scale (0: Never or rarely, 3: Always) (Poulin, Hand, & Boudreau, 2005). 
Attachment Style: Measured through the Adolescent Attachment Questionnaire (West et al., 1998; nine items rated on a 7-point scale, 1: Not at all like me, 7: Very much like me) (e.g., “I feel for my parent when he/she is upset.”). 
Subjective task commitment: Measured via one item (“How much do you think your participation contributed to this study?”) rated on a 5 point scale (1: Not at all, 5: To a great extent). 
GPA: Cumulative and year GPAs will be gathered from the student information system data of the Character Lab.
Items for each of the scale will be averaged into one scale score. As the given scales showed high reliability in previous studies, we do not anticipate any problems with averaging these scores.

We will run bivariate correlations to examine the relationship between paradoxical knowing and the variables of interest (see hypotheses)

We will also replicate the correlational analyses by controlling for other knowing measures (concordant knowing, believing, concordant not-knowing, and paradoxical not-knowing).

q20.value: We do not anticipate any need for transforming the data. However, if any skewness is detected, we will transform the data by using conventional ways of data transformation.

q21.value: We will use a p-value of .05 as our criterion for determining significance.

q22.value: We will exclude participants who fail the attention check question within the survey (where participants are asked to write the word "yes" in a box). We do not expect to exclude outliers unless they emerge as a result of an error during data collection.

q23.value: Participants who miss more than 33% of the questions for any of the questionnaires will be excluded only from the analyses involving that questionnaire.

q24.value:
We will content-analyze the open-ended reports of paradoxical knowing (qualitatively) to understand better the domains where paradoxical knowing emerges among adolescents.

We will run exploratory mediation analyses (by assessing indirect models with 10000 bootstrapped samples and bias-corrected 95% confidence intervals) by including the variables that were found to be significantly correlated with paradoxical knowing in the models. For instance, we will examine whether the relationship between the (low) feeling of being understood and determined ignorance is mediated by paradoxical knowing. 

We will also explore how participants’ subjective feeling of commitment to the study affects our findings through exploratory analyses. 

Finally, we will follow-up with the participants in the next data collection cycle of the Character Lab to examine the hypothesized effects in a longitudinal design. Specifically, we will examine the relationship between the change in PK over time with the change in the variables that are hypothesized to be related to PK (e.g., how does the change in PK relates to the change in aggression). We will conduct both analyses of difference (by taking the difference between the scores at Time 2 and the scores at Time 1 and including difference scores in the GLM analyses) as well as cross-lagged analyses by including data from the two time-points in the models.

registration_responses.q1: Supporting adolescents to thrive despite uncertainty: An analysis of the psychological correlates of paradoxical knowing
registration_responses.q2: The Motivation Lab, Irmak Olcaysoy Okten
registration_responses.q3:
The present study aims to investigate what makes students vulnerable to holding a "paradoxical knowledge," namely, having strong feelings of certainty for the things that are technically unknowable. It will also analyze potential academic and interpersonal correlates that may make this shortcut to knowledge problematic for the person who has fallen prey to it (e.g., showing impulsive thinking) as well as for the people around them (e.g., whether paradoxical knowing is related to a determination to ignore opposing views of others). 

Our research questions are as follows:
1) Can the phenomenon of paradoxical knowing (one's claim to know something while recognizing its unknowability) be measured among high school students (qualitatively and quantitatively)?
2) Does adolescents’ chronic tendency to hold paradoxical knowledge relate to antisocial behaviors and intuitive thinking (as observed in adults previously)?
3. Are there other correlates of paradoxical knowledge (other than the factors observed in previous studies), including one’s avoidance of taking responsibility for their own actions (e.g., externalization), social isolation, and lack of intellectual humility?
registration_responses.q4:
We hypothesize that paradoxical knowing will be significantly related to the following variables:

-Greater anti-social behaviors (determined ignorance and aggression)
-Greater intuitive thinking (higher self-reported impulsivity, higher behavioral impulsivity, lower need for cognition)
-Greater social isolation (a lower level of social belonging and the feeling of being understood, a greater level of perception of self-victimhood)
-A lower level of taking responsibility for one's own actions (higher externalization, detachment, and stonewalling)
-A lower level of intellectual humility

We hypothesize that paradoxical knowing will not be related to the following variables: 

-Self-esteem
-Depression
-Self-efficacy

We will explore the relationship between paradoxical knowing and the following variables: 

-Bullying experiences (getting bullied and bullying)
-School performance (Self-reported (objective) school performance, subjective school performance, GPA)
-Self-perception on the traits of tenderness, gentle-heartedness, forcefulness, assertiveness, kindness, dominance
-Defensiveness, contempt, and criticism
-Shame and guilt
-Empathy and perspective-taking
-Adolescent attachment style
-Trait anxiety
-Regret
-Narcissism
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: Participants will be randomized into conditions at the individual-level through logic built into our Qualtrics survey.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We anticipate that approximately 1000-1200 students will participate in this study. However, this number may vary depending on the success of recruitment at the schools.
registration_responses.q14: A power analysis suggests that for an alpha level of .05, an effect size of 0.12 and 80% power, 1090 would be required for this study.
registration_responses.q20: We do not anticipate any need for transforming the data. However, if any skewness is detected, we will transform the data by using conventional ways of data transformation.
registration_responses.q21: We will use a p-value of .05 as our criterion for determining significance.
registration_responses.q22: We will exclude participants who fail the attention check question within the survey (where participants are asked to write the word "yes" in a box). We do not expect to exclude outliers unless they emerge as a result of an error during data collection.
registration_responses.q23: Participants who miss more than 33% of the questions for any of the questionnaires will be excluded only from the analyses involving that questionnaire.

registration_responses.q8.question: Correlational Design
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network (CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.
 
CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.
 
CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers.
 
For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer to https://characterlab.org/research-network.
registration_responses.q16.question: There are no manipulated variables in this study.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Paradoxical knowing (PK) (open-ended): Participants are asked to report one personal experience of paradoxical knowing in an open-ended fashion. 
Ease of PK recall: One question of rating the ease of recalling the PK experience that was just reported (1: Extremely easy, 7: Extremely difficult). 
Determined ignorance: Five items assessing the tendency to ignore others’ opinions (e.g., “You don't really have to consider all information.” (Gollwitzer & Oettingen, 2019). 
PK (chronic), Concordant Knowing, Believing, Concordant not knowing, Paradoxical not Knowing: Each of the five variables is measured through three items, rated on a 7 point scale (1: Not at all agree, 7: Strongly agree) (Gollwitzer & Oettingen, 2019). 
Empathy and Perspective Taking: Seven item subscales of each borrowed from the Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davis, 1980) (e.g., “I am often quite touched by things that I see happen.”, “When I'm upset at someone, I usually try to "put myself in his shoes" for a while.”). 
Self-reported (objective) school performance: One item measuring average score in the current school year (options: less than 60%, 60-69%. 70-79%, 80% or high, don’t know). Getting bullied: The frequency of getting bullied since the start of the school year rated on a 5-item scale, (0: Not at all-4: Many times a week) (Wang et al., 2014). 
Bullying: The frequency of bullying others since the start of the school year rated on a 5-item scale, (0: Not at all-4: Many times a week) (Wang et al., 2014). 
Aggression: The tendency to hold aggressive attitudes, measured through 5 items on a 7-point scale (1: Strongly disagree, 7: Strongly agree) (e.g., “In general, the only way to rid the world of bad ideas is through the use of force.”, Crowson, 2009). 
Self-reported impulsiveness: The tendency of impulsivity and restraint measured via four items (2 items for each subscale) selected from the Brief Self-control Scale (1: Not at all like me, 5: Very much like me) (Tangney et al., 2004) (e.g., “I have a hard time breaking bad habits.”). 
Behavioral impulsiveness: Measured via Cognitive Reflection Task (Frederick, 2005), including three calculation questions. 
Perceived victimhood: Perception of being a victim compared to others, measured via three items on a 7-point scale (1: Strongly disagree, 7: Strongly agree) (e.g., “In general, I have suffered more than most of my peers.”, adapted from Noor et al., 2008). 
Need for cognition: Measured via three items selected from Keller et al. (2019) on a 7 point scale (1: Not true at all, 7: Extremely true) (e.g., “I like to do puzzles.”). 
Feeling of being understood: Measured via five items adapted from Livingstone et al. (2019), rated on a 7-point scale (1: Not true at all, 7: Extremely true) (e.g., “My peers generally understand my values.”). 
Intellectual humility: Measured via five items selected from Leary et al. (2017), rated on a 7-point scale (1: Not at all like me, 7: Very much like me) (e.g., “I accept that my beliefs and attitudes may be wrong”). 
Self-efficacy:  Measuring academic, social, and emotional self-efficacy (1 item per each) selected from Muris’ (2001) scale, rated on a 7-point scale (1: Not well at all, 7: Extremely well). 
Subjective school performance: Rating of self-performance regardless of grades, how well they think they perform at school (1: Extremely poorly, 7: Extremely Well), and their certainty for subjective academic performance (1: Not certain at all, 7: Extremely certain).
Four horsemen of the apocalypse: Criticism, contempt, stonewalling and defensiveness measured via three items (each) selected from Fowler & Dillow’s (2011) scale, rated on a 7-point scale (1: Not true at all, 7: Extremely True) (e.g., for stonewalling, “If I can tell a disagreement is brewing, I kind of shut down and stop talking.”). 
Regret: Measured via five items selected from Schwartz et al. (2002) and on a 7-point scale (1: Strongly disagree, 7: Strongly agree) (e.g., “Whenever I make a choice, I’m curious about what would have happened if I had chosen differently.”). 
Self-Attributional Style (shame, guilt, detachment, and externalization): Measured through TOSCA (Tangney et al., 1991), where participants rate their likelihood of engaging in those four different types of responses in four different (selected) scenarios, rated on a 5-point scale (1: Not at all likely, 5: Very likely) (e.g., “While playing around, you throw a ball, and it hits your friend in the face.”). 
Self-esteem: One item of self-reported self-esteem on a 7-point scale (“I have high self-esteem”; 1: Not at all true of me, 7: Extremely true of me). 
Social belonging: 2 items borrowed from Ingram (2012), rated on a 7-point scale, 1: Strongly disagree, 7: Strongly Agree). 
Self-Trait judgments: Participants evaluate themselves on six traits (tender, gentle-hearted, forceful, assertive, kind, dominant) on a 7-point scale (1: Extremely inaccurate, 7: Extremely accurate). 
Narcissism: Measured via three items from the Childhood Narcissism Scale (Thomaes et al., 2008) on a 4-point scale (0: Not at all true, 3: Completely True) (e.g., “Kids like me deserve something extra”). 
Trait Anxiety: Frequency of symptoms measured via four items selected from Spielberger (1983), rated on a 4-point scale (0: Not at all, 3: Very much so). 
Depression: Measured via a short version of CES-D with 12 items (experience of certain psychological states in the last seven days) rated on a 4-point scale (0: Never or rarely, 3: Always) (Poulin, Hand, & Boudreau, 2005). 
Attachment Style: Measured through the Adolescent Attachment Questionnaire (West et al., 1998; nine items rated on a 7-point scale, 1: Not at all like me, 7: Very much like me) (e.g., “I feel for my parent when he/she is upset.”). 
Subjective task commitment: Measured via one item (“How much do you think your participation contributed to this study?”) rated on a 5 point scale (1: Not at all, 5: To a great extent). 
GPA: Cumulative and year GPAs will be gathered from the student information system data of the Character Lab.
registration_responses.q18.question: Items for each of the scale will be averaged into one scale score. As the given scales showed high reliability in previous studies, we do not anticipate any problems with averaging these scores.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will run bivariate correlations to examine the relationship between paradoxical knowing and the variables of interest (see hypotheses)

We will also replicate the correlational analyses by controlling for other knowing measures (concordant knowing, believing, concordant not-knowing, and paradoxical not-knowing).

q1.value: When humans are replaced by digital team members. Effects of role and task knowledge on trust and user acceptance, and the moderating role of task experience.

q2.value: Thomas Ellwart, Benedikt Graf, Lukas Reuter, Jan Ole Berndt, Ingo J. Timm, Conny Herbert Antoni

q3.value:
At the digital workplace teams with hybrid structures of digital and human members work together (Endsley, 2017; Fiore & Wiltshire, 2016; You & Robert, 2018). Especially the replacement of a human team member (e.g. with a digital one) is a critical aspect for successful teamwork that is often discussed (Emurian, Canfield, & Brady, 2010; Summers, Humphrey, & Ferris, 2012; Wasen, 2010). Particularly, in the replacement phase aspects of trust and acceptance are critical factors for future successful cooperation.
Theories of team cognition underline the importance of task and role knowledge as a critical predictor of successful teamwork. In this study, task and role knowledge about a digital team member is applied to hybrid teams consisting of human actors and software agents. Following team as well as human factor research (Venkatesh, Morris, & Davis, 2003), we postulate that role and task knowledge regaring the new digital team member predicts trust and user acceptance before the first collaboration task is done. User acceptance comprises two facets: effort and performance expectancies. Performance expectancies describes the perceived usefulness of a digital system and subsequently, the intention to use or work with it, while effort expectancies describe the perceived efforts that are necessary when working with a digital system (Venkatesh, et al., 2003). Differentiating pre- and post-action processes (Marks, Mathieu, & Zaccaro, 2001) we assume that positive and negative experiences will also influence the effects of role and task knowledge regarding software agents on post action evaluations of trust and user acceptance. Furthermore, we expect that task experiences with respect to the outcomes of the socio-digital collaboration, providing feedback from the task itself, influence the relation between role and task knowledge, trust and user acceptance. Therefore, we integrate theories from team research as well as human factor research, which offer validated evidence, in order to predict human reactions to the staffing of a team with digital software agents. 
In a laboratory experiment, three team members work on an interdependent task. After one of the team members drops out, it is replaced by artificial intelligence (digital software agent). The remaining two team members are either informed or not informed about the roles and tasks of the software agent and evaluate the software agent before and after the first collaboration task. The research questions are: (1) Does high (vs. low) knowledge about the roles and tasks of digital team members influence the acceptance and trust of the digital team member (T1)? (2) Do positive (vs. negative) task experiences and performance feedback during the first hybrid collaboration influence trust and acceptance at T2?

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1. Team members with role and task knowledge have higher levels of trust towards the new digital team-member prior to the first action phase than team members without role and task knowledge.

Hypothesis 2. Team members with role and task knowledge have higher levels of performance expectancy towards the new digital team-member prior collaboration than team members without role and task knowledge. 

Hypothesis 3. Team members with role and task knowledge have higher levels of effort expectancy towards the new digital team-member prior collaboration than team members without role and task knowledge.

Hypothesis 4. Team members with role and task knowledge have higher post action (a) trust, (b) performance, and (c) effort expectancy than team members without role and task knowledge. 

Hypothesis 5. Experience will moderate the effects of role and task knowledge on (a) trust, (b) performance and (c) effort expectancy in post-action phase.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The experiment will follow a 1 factor design with 2 levels (with vs. without role and task knowledge about the digital agent). Predictor variables/ independent variables as well as criterion variables/ dependet variables will be assessed on individual level.

q9.value: The participants register via the experimental subjects portal of the University of Trier. The time slots are randomly allocated to the different conditions. The participants register for these time slots without knowing their allocation.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Participants will be students from a German university who take part in the experiment for course credit or reimbursement (1.5 credits or 15 €). We calculated the sample size to be N = 70 teams, each team consisting of 2 participants and 1 digital agent leading to a total of 140 participants.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 140 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 200 participants, assuming some participant dropping out of the experiment or disrupting the experiment.

q14.value: f = .25 (medium), sig. level = .01, power = .8 resulting in n ~ 70 teams per condition (one-way design) leading to 140 participants

question.value: Manipulation of role and task knowledge. Teams were either provided with knowledge about the digital agent that replaced the dropped out team member or they received no information about the digital agent. The given knowledge refered to teamwork (i.e. roles and expertise) and taskwork (i.e. interactions, goals) knowledge. This differentiation from teamwork research (DeChurch & Mesmer-Magnus, 2010b, 2010a) is similarly reflected in human factors. We followed the model of understanding digital systems by Schaefer et al. (2016). Teamwork knowledge related to the facet of “understanding of the digital agent” and “self perceived ability”; taskwork knowledge refered to “expectancy concerning the digital agent”.

Performance Expectancy and effort expectancy. Both facets of user acceptance were measured with three items each adapted from Venkatesh et al. (2003). E.g., 'I would find the use of the digital agent as a team member useful in the task' for performance expectancy;  'The interaction with the digital agent would be clear and understandable' for effort expectancy (1 = disagree, 6 = strongly agree).

Trust. A three-item scale from Hertel et al. (2019) was slightly adapted to the setting of the experiment, e.g. 'I trust the digital agent completely' or 'I rely heavily on the digital agent' (1 = disagree, 6 = strongly agree).  

Experience. Experience was measured with 3 items. One Item was adapted from Hinkle, Taylor, Fox-Cardamone, and Crook (1989) (‘I think that this socio-digital team has worked well together’), and two items were adapted from Hoegl and Gemuenden (2001), e.g. ‘Looking at the result of the work phase, the task completion in the team can be described as successful’ (1 = disagree, 6 = strongly agree).

The analyses will be performed with SPSS 26; including ANOVAs for Pre-Action (T1) and ANOVAs for post action (T2) phase. 
The moderating effect of experience will be analyzed with hayes macro (model 1) moderation model.

q20.value: Categorial variables will be dummy coded (Role and task knowledge with vs. without).

q23.value: If too few people appear for the experiment, they will be offered an alternative date.

attributes.title: Models of care for frail older persons who present to the emergency department: A scoping review of the literature

summary.value:
Background: Worldwide, the population of people aged over 60 is rapidly increasing from 900 million in 2015 to an estimated 2 billion by 2050. People aged 65 years and over comprise around 1 in 5 presentations in the emergency department (ED). Many of these presentations occur as a result of complications related to chronic diseases and frailty.

Objective: This scoping review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of available research evidence with regards to models of care for frail older people presenting to the ED.

Method: The Joanna Briggs Institute scoping review framework will be used to guide this review. Population is frail older people; concept is model of care; and context is the ED. This review will consider published peer-review primary research articles to answer the review question. Studies published in the English language between January 2009-October 2019 will be included in this review. Search will be conducted in the databases of CHINAHL via EBSCOhost, Ovid MEDLINE, Embase, SocINDEX and google scholar. The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis (PRISMA flow diagram) will be used to report the search and screening process.  All included studies will be appraised using National Health and Medical Research Council level of evidence hierarchy body of evidence matrix. Data will be presented in a tabular format and accompanied by a narrative that describes the characteristics of the body of literature.

q1.value: The Behavioral, Emotional, and Social Skills Inventory (BESSI 1.0): Measurement properties and links with student outcomes.

q2.value: Madison Sewell, Christopher Napolitano, Christopher J. Soto, Brent Roberts

q3.value:
This study is designed to examine the basic measurement properties of the Behavioral, Emotional, and Social Skills Inventory, Version 1.0 (BESSI 1.0), as well as age differences in BESSI scores and associations of the BESSI with student outcomes. Our key research questions are:

1) How internally consistent are the BESSI facet scales?
2) How well-differentiated are the BESSI facet scales?
3) Does the BESSI have a clear multidimensional structure?
4) Are there mean-level age differences in the BESSI facets and domains?
5) Does the BESSI relate with student outcomes in conceptually meaningful ways?

q4.value:
1) We expect that alpha reliabilities for the BESSI 1.0 facet scales will average at least .70, and will all be at least .50.
2) We expect that most correlations between BESSI facet scales will be positive (reflecting a positive manifold for BES skills), but less than .90 (indicating that the facets are not entirely redundant).
3) We expect that the BESSI will have a five-dimensional structure when tested using exploratory factor analysis, with domains reflecting social engagement, cooperation, self-regulation, emotional resilience, and intellectual engagement.
4) We expect that scores on BESSI domains and facets will generally increase by participant grade level/age.
5) We expect that the BESSI domains will relate with student outcomes in a number of conceptually-meaningful ways. See the attached pdf for specific predictions.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is an observational study without any between-subject or within-subject manipulations.

question.value:
Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network (CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.
 
CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.
 
CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers.
 
For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer to https://characterlab.org/research-network.

q13.value: CLRN expects a sample size of approximately 1,000 participants for this study.

q14.value: This sample size would provide 88.8% power to detect a small effect (r = .10), and greater than 99.9% power to detect a medium-sized (r = .30) or large  (r = .50) effect, using two-tailed tests at the .05

q15.value: This study will be run through CLRN’s Qualtrics-supported online platform that randomizes all students at the network schools into multiple CLRN studies on their predetermined testing day. This study has a quota equal to the sample size specified above

question.value: This observational study does not include any manipulated variables.

The main predictors will be the 32 BESSI 1.0 facets, and the five expected domains derived from these facets.

The main outcomes will be life satisfaction (measured using Satisfaction With Life Scale); popularity (measured using an item from the Behavior Report Form); social status (measured using an item adapted from Anderson, John, Keltner, & Kring, 2001); friendship quality (measured using an abbreviated version of the Friendship Qualities Scale); romantic relationship satisfaction (measured using two items from the Dyadic Adjustment Scale); parental relationship quality (measured using six items adapted from the Dunedin Study); academic engagement measured using an abbreviated version of the Engagement versus Disaffection with Learning scale); exercise (measured using the Godin Leisure Time Exercise Questionnaire); volunteerism (measured using four items from Carlo, Okun, Knight, & de Guzman, 2005); and occupational interests (measured using the O*Net Mini Interest Profiler), as well as student information system data on attendance, report card grades, and discipline provided by the CLRN.

The main covariates are student grade level and gender.

The 32 BESSI facet scales will be scored from their constituent items using simple item aggregation. See the attached Excel file for a list of items and scale assignments.

Domain scales for the BESSI will be derived from principal components analyses (PCAs) and exploratory factor analyses (EFAs) of the BESSI facet scales. The assignment of facets to domains will depend on the PCA and EFA results, as well as conceptual considerations, and is therefore exploratory. However, all decisions about assigning the BESSI facets to domains will be made before we conduct any analyses to test associations between the BESSI scores and student outcomes. After assigning facets to domains, we will derive two sets of domain scores: one from simple aggregation of the facet scores, and one from factor scores for a selected PCA or EFA of the facet scales.

All outcome measures are previously published, and we will compute outcome scores following the published scoring instructions for each measure. For most outcome measures, scale scores are computed using simple item aggregation.

1) Internal consistency of the BESSI facet scales will be tested using Cronbach’s alpha reliability coefficient.
2) Differentiation between the BESSI facet scales will be tested using Pearson’s correlation coefficients.
3) The multidimensional structure of the BESSI will be tested using PCAs and EFAs of the 32 BESSI facet scales. These analyses will be repeated using both orthogonal (varimax) and oblique (promax) rotations.
4) Age differences in the BESSI domains and facets will be tested using one-way ANOVAs, with grade level as a fixed factor.
5) Associations of the BESSI domains with student outcomes will be tested using Pearson’s correlation coefficients and multiple regression analyses. In the regression analyses, we will first analyze associations on a domain-by-domain basis, then all BESSI domains will be entered simultaneously as predictors. The correlation and regression analyses will be repeated both with and without gender and grade level as covariates.

q20.value: Number of disciplinary incidents may be transformed to reduce the influence of outliers. All decisions about whether and how to transform this variable will be made after examining its frequency distribution, but before testing its associations with the BESSI domains and facets.

q21.value: All tests will be two-tailed tests using the .05 significance level. To avoid interpreting statistically significant but trivially small effects, interpretation will focus on effect sizes (r/β) of .10 or greater.

q22.value: The study’s survey includes two pairs of attention-check items: one pair near the end of the BESSI, and one pair near the end of the outcome battery. Participants who fail either BESSI attention check item will be excluded from all analyses. Participants who pass both BESSI attention check items, but then fail either outcome attention check item, will be excluded from all analyses of the outcome measures.

q23.value: For participants who pass the relevant attention and completion checks, each missing response will be imputed as the sample’s mean response to that item, rounded to the nearest possible response option.

q24.value:
There may be individual differences in acquiescent response style on the BESSI. We will therefore examine whether accounting for these individual differences (e.g., using within-person centering or random-intercept EFA) affects the BESSI’s multidimensional structure.

We may use the PCA/EFA results to develop and test confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) models of the BESSI’s multidimensional structure.

We will examine possible gender differences in the BESSI domains and facets using independent-samples t-tests, as well as two-way ANOVAs with grade level and gender as fixed factors.

We will also examine relations of the BESSI facets with student outcomes using correlation and regression analyses. We will repeat these analyses both with and without grade level and gender as covariates.

registration_responses.q1: The Behavioral, Emotional, and Social Skills Inventory (BESSI 1.0): Measurement properties and links with student outcomes.
registration_responses.q2: Madison Sewell, Christopher Napolitano, Christopher J. Soto, Brent Roberts
registration_responses.q3:
This study is designed to examine the basic measurement properties of the Behavioral, Emotional, and Social Skills Inventory, Version 1.0 (BESSI 1.0), as well as age differences in BESSI scores and associations of the BESSI with student outcomes. Our key research questions are:

1) How internally consistent are the BESSI facet scales?
2) How well-differentiated are the BESSI facet scales?
3) Does the BESSI have a clear multidimensional structure?
4) Are there mean-level age differences in the BESSI facets and domains?
5) Does the BESSI relate with student outcomes in conceptually meaningful ways?
registration_responses.q4:
1) We expect that alpha reliabilities for the BESSI 1.0 facet scales will average at least .70, and will all be at least .50.
2) We expect that most correlations between BESSI facet scales will be positive (reflecting a positive manifold for BES skills), but less than .90 (indicating that the facets are not entirely redundant).
3) We expect that the BESSI will have a five-dimensional structure when tested using exploratory factor analysis, with domains reflecting social engagement, cooperation, self-regulation, emotional resilience, and intellectual engagement.
4) We expect that scores on BESSI domains and facets will generally increase by participant grade level/age.
5) We expect that the BESSI domains will relate with student outcomes in a number of conceptually-meaningful ways. See the attached pdf for specific predictions.

attributes.title: The effects of Ujjwala on personal PM2.5 exposure: Evidence from Bihar, India
attributes.description: This study will evaluate the relationship between a new LPG connection, traditional biomass stove use, and personal exposure to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in 50 households in rural Bihar, India over a nine-month monitoring period.

q1.value: The effects of Ujjwala on personal PM2.5 exposure:  Evidence from Bihar, India

q2.value: Carlos Gould, Faraz Usmani, Ajay Pillarisetti, SP Harish, Johannes Urpelainen

q3.value: More than 70 million rural Indian households have benefited from subsidized liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) connections since May 2016 through the Government of India’s Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana (PMUY) scheme. PMUY has the potential to improve population health throughout India through reductions in air pollution exposure from household transitions to clean cooking fuels from traditional cooking with biomass like firewood, dung, and agricultural residues. This study will evaluate the relationship between a new LPG connection, traditional biomass stove use, and personal exposure to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in 50 households in rural Bihar, India over a nine-month monitoring period. Specifically, we will estimate 1) the degree to which LPG acquired through PMUY displaces traditional biomass stove use using stove use monitors; 2) the change in personal PM2.5 exposure after LPG adoption and the extent to which LPG has led to PM2.5 exposure below the World Health Organization interim-I guideline of 35 g/m3 using lightweight time-resolved and gravimetric sensors; and 3) the determinants of observed cooking fuel use patterns. Households will be visited each month during which stove use and PM2.5 exposure will be monitored during a 48-hour period and a questionnaire will be administered once.

q4.value:
H1: We hypothesize that the average minutes of use of traditional biomass stove during the 48-hour monitoring periods will be lower after LPG stove adoption but will reach zero for only a small number of households (<10%).

H2: We hypothesize a moderate decline in average 48-hour PM2.5 exposure after LPG stove adoption. 

H3: We hypothesize that a very small number of households (<5%) will average 48-hour PM2.5 exposure below 35 ug/m3 in the baseline period and after LPG adoption, a significantly higher proportion of households will have average 48-hour PM2.5 below the WHO interim-I guideline but still more than half (>50%) will have 48-hour PM2.5 above the guideline.

H4: We hypothesize that both the number of minutes of biomass stove use during the 48-hour monitoring period and average 48-hour personal PM2.5 exposure will increase with the number of months after LPG adoption. 

H5: We hypothesize that markers of higher socioeconomic status and closer proximity to distributors will be predictors of LPG stove use.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Please reference the main document, as well as the attached Appendices for full description of data collection procedures and survey instruments. 


We propose to recruit 50 non-LPG-owning households from two peri-urban villages outside of Patna, Bihar in January 2020. We will identify districts or blocks of relatively low LPG penetration using local field workers and Government data on LPG connections. In an ideal situation, these villages will have LPG connection-rollouts through PMUY upcoming during 2020. After identifying two to three villages for the study, field workers will carry out a rapid census of households (N=50 or more in each village) to identify interested households without LPG and reliant on a solid fuel for cooking. In this case, interest refers both to willingness to participate in the study and also interest in acquiring LPG prior to our involvement. If we identify >25 households in each village that do not have LPG and are interested, we will randomly select 25 households in each village. 

At enrollment all participating households will have no LPG and rely on a solid fuel for cooking. One field worker will visit each participating household for one monitoring period per month for nine months. Each visit will be comprised of a short visit on day one where the enumerator will administer a short survey and set up sensor-based air pollution and stove use monitoring. In addition, the enumerator will set up an area for biomass to be used during the 48-hour period. The enumerator will then return after at least 48-hours have elapsed to retrieve the equipment and administer a post-monitoring period survey. Generally, the enumerator will reach seven households to carry out parallel 48-hour monitoring periods.

q14.value: Sample size due to time and budgetary constraints. Expected power achieved is detailed fully in the Main Document: Pre Analysis Plan.
